# Different opinions on increased minimum wage
### With the arrival of the new year comes another increase in minimum wage in the US. For example minimum wage raises from _14.13_ to _15.13_ in New York and _14.20_ to _15.00_ in New Jersey. This article will be focusing on this phenomenon, and providing some common but different views on this act.

## **Article 1**:  _Raising the Minimum Wage Would Be an Investment in Growing the Middle Class_ 
[article link](https://www.americanprogress.org/article/raising-the-minimum-wage-would-be-an-investment-in-growing-the-middle-class/)


### Advocates of increasing minimum wage states that it is helpful in increasing Middle Class's wealth, and benefit the lowest income group most.

![wage increse by sex](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

### My opinion on this article: 

 ### The aruthor might have listed convincing data evidence of increasing wage in minority group after the increase in minimumwage. But I would say more information is required to prove the impacts of increasing minimum wage, because most of economic acts have two sides of effects. Maybe workers in specific industry or groups are benefited more than others. Maybe the price level is changing alongside nominal wage, making the purchasing power actually unchanged.

 ### Besides, the evidence listed in the article might only be a short term effect, because if it remains the same way in the long run, the government could improve the economy simply by increasing minimum wage indefinitely, which is clearly unreasonable. (We all see the results of infinitely printing currencies before. )

 ## **Article 2**: _Research: When a Higher Minimum Wage Leads to Lower Compensation_
 [Articlelink](https://hbr.org/2021/06/research-when-a-higher-minimum-wage-leads-to-lower-compensation)

### Researchers from Harverd Univeristy has proved that it is a flase statement that increasing minimum wage does no harm at all. Instead, firms responds to increase in minimum wage in a very tricky way, usually they stratigically change their approaches in workers' schedules or other things, which may largely influence workers' overall welfare.
> ### They found that " For every $1 increase in the minimum wage, the total number of workers scheduled to work each week increased by 27.7%, while the average number of hours each worker worked per week decrease by 20.8%. For an average store in California, these changes translated into four extra workers per week and five fewer hours per worker per week â€” which meant that the total wage compensation of an average minimum wage worker in a California store actually fell by 13.6%."

### My opinion on this article:

### This article proves my thought that every act has both pros and cons. If the government raises the minimum wage, the firm will must respond to this act in their ways, because it is human nature that they work for their own good. If a $1 increase in minimum wage led to more workers scheduled but fewer hours per worker per week. It would only result in a decrease in total wage compensation, eligibility for benefits, and increased scheduling inconsistencies

### Overall, I believe there must be certain groups of people get benefited by the act, just like Article 1 has stated, but no doubts there are people paying cost at the same time. So I would still hold an indifferent position. The important thing is about long-term effect. Questions we should pay attention to includes whether increasing minimum wage will leads to higher price level; whether the firms will turn to automation instead of human resources to compensate the loss; whether rasing minimum wage would exacerbate income disparities and the cycle of poverty. These are what we should consider about.
